Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2018 02:55PM Groovywilma wrote: I am ER+, PR+, HER2- I've been Stage IV for 7 years (my initial diagnosis). For the first 6 years it was in my bones only and my treatments were mild and manageable. I worked, traveled, and lived pretty "normally". A year ago it spread to my liver and I've been on heavier chemo that wipes me out and took my hair! But I'm hoping that the chemo continues to be effective and last a long time before having to switch to the next treatment. I'm hoping for many more new effective treatment options for everyone!!!
Posts.Title: ER+ PR+ HER - longterm survival sharethehope Celebrate_Life

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2016 09:07AM Groovywilma wrote: I am approaching my 6th year with bone mets. I did well on the AI's (two years on Arimidex, two years on Faslodex and a couple of others that didn't last as long). I started chemotherapy for the first time in April 2016. We haven't checked if my hormone status has changed, but my doctor suspects that after this much time, the cancer probably has figured out a way around the AI's, which is why we decided it was time for chemo. Wishing you all the best!

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 11:53AM Groovywilma wrote: I'm getting a PET scan this week on Thursday.  My instructions say "eat a low carb diet" day before exam (does not give me any suggestions, so the suggestions you guys listed about are very helpful!).  Don't engage in strenuous activity or exercise.  On the day of I'm just to drink water before I come in.  I usually eat an omelet, a salad, and some meat and vegies for dinner.  And all day I think about all the things I want to eat that, for just this day, I can't eat!  Does anyone have to scan in a machine that is in a mobile trailer?  The machine I go to is parked in the parking lot at a different medical center and is there only on Thursdays and Fridays.  It goes to other centers on other days.  Good luck to everyone with upcoming scans!  I hope the results are good!!!

Pre-meds were the same as my one hour taxol: Kytrel, Pepcid, Decadron, and Benadryl. I didn't notice much of a difference with the 3 hour infusion. I will be monitoring any side effects and symptoms for the next week. I did get the On-Pro Neulasta. It's on my arm right now and will administer the medication 27 hours after my chemo was finished. Best of luck to you Keetmom!
Posts.Title: every 3 week toxil keetmom keetmom

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2017 04:56PM Groovywilma wrote: Keetmom, OK, you have to tell me how it went this morning and how you are feeling? What pre-meds did you do and how long were you there? Wishing you well! Take care!
Posts.Title: every 3 week toxil keetmom keetmom

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2017 03:04AM Groovywilma wrote: So far I like the every three week schedule versus the three weeks on, one week off. It let's me enjoy the second and third week having more energy before having to go back. This dose seems to be pretty hard on my red blood cells and I've been more anemic with this dose. I have been doing the Procrit injections, but even weekly it hasn't boosted the red blood cells. I almost was going to have a blood transfusion this week, but the pharmacists want to monitor for another week or two to see about increasing the dose of Procrit or deciding to do the blood transfusion (and they will discuss with my doctor when he comes back from vacation). I've been on Neulasta and the bad part is the bone pain I get from the medication stimulating those white blood cells. No fun! But the good things is that it's keeping those white blood cells in a good range. I'm getting the neuropathy in my fingers and toes and today was given a prescription for gabapentin. I've also been experiencing tingling in my chin/ lower lip which I think might be neuropathy, which is pretty uncommon. I have an MRI scheduled to check it out. So that's my experience so far with the Taxol every three weeks. I'm hoping for good results when I do my next PET scan (probably next month). And I am considering my options of going back to work... a hard decision to make!

My doctor has the great outlook of making sure my treatment doesn't interfere with my travels if possible. I have continued to work throughout treatment because I have a job I like with some flexibility and a lot of understanding. I only started chemo this year because I was able to do the anti-hormonal treatments for a while that were very effective for me. I wish you the best of luck! You can definitely still LIVE and enjoy life. You'll certainly have challenges, but I hope you do great!

Posts.Title: GEMZAR WarriorG RosesToeses

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2017 03:27AM Groovywilma wrote: I was on Gemzar and it was quite manageable for me. It was my first IV chemotherapy. I got a port for it and was on it 3 weeks on, 1 week off. I continued to work full time while on Gemzar. Side effects for me: fatigue, some constipation, anemia. I took Procrit to help the anemia. I took metamucil to help with the constipation. I had quite a bit of hair thinning when I first started it, but not many people noticed this (I have thick hair to start with, so that helped). It started growing back in and thickening up after six months or so. Unfortunately after 10 months I had progress so I had to change treatment. I would not have minded staying on Gemzar longer! Pre-meds included decadron and zofran. I am getting zometa quarterly. If you have any questions, let me know! PM me in case I miss reading things. Sometimes I don't get around to reading everything! Good luck and I hope you guys get some excellent mileage out of Gemzar!
Posts.Title: GEMZAR WarriorG RosesToeses

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 10:56PM Groovywilma wrote: Weather is great in southern california as well!  I just got done with my swimming class!  I'm trying to learn how to swim and breathe at the same time!  Also, it's good exercise (considering I haven't been doing any exercising lately).  I'm going to my cousin's birthday bash later this evening.  I also think about: if my time is limited, what do I want to be doing with it?  Generally I try to live my life as if I don't have stage IV breast cancer and at the same time, make sure that I am doing things that I WANT to be doing (and sometimes that means lounging in my PJs all Saturday afternoon as well!). Enjoy the weekend!

You're right, everything is so varied that it's hard to get the specific answers. Thank you (and everyone here) for sharing your knowledge and resources. I want to continue working as long as I can, but want to know if there is a way to get the clock started for date of disability for medicare in the future. For example, take a short leave of absence, and then return to work. Not sure if that is doable. But that's why I'm researching now! Thanks!
Posts.Title: Financial and Career Implications of Cancer LynnFish Lumpie

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 07:37PM Groovywilma wrote: Sorry to hear that you are stage IV now.  I was diagnosed stage IV from the start about a year and a half ago.  I've stayed at my job this whole time, just taking time off for my doctor's appointments once a month and scans when needed.  I am on Arimidex, Lupron every three months, and Zometa monthly and hope that I can stay on this regimen for a long time.  If my job was stressful and I hated it, it would be a different story, but as it is, I enjoy what I do, my team has been very supportive and understanding and I can earn my paycheck to use for the traveling I want to do.  We have to live our lives the best way we can, so determining if that means working or not is key.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Keep working or not? Questions from a newbie Carla9112 lisalock

Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 02:14AM Groovywilma wrote: My PET report reads:  There are innumerable hypermetabolic skeletal lesions involving the entire spine, multiple ribs, sternum, skull base, pelvis and femurs.  Sucks!!! I just got diagnosed in January 2011 but through most of last year (and especially towards the end of the year) I was having lower back/ hip pain.  Similar to you, my main pain was in my right hip, and in my left groin area and this caused me to limp and walk funny.  I went to physical therapy with only minor relief.  Found out in January that it is cancer hanging out in my bones!   In October I had this sharp pain in my left side.  I went to the doc who said it was possibly a rib sprain (even though I did nothing to cause such a thing).  In retrospect, I think I know what it REALLY is now! I still have the pain in my hip/ groin but it's not too bad.  I can't walk as far or as fast as I used to, but for the most part it is manageable with ibuprofen.  I have vicoden also but that does not really help.  We haven't done any radiation at this time because the doc says the cancer isn't in any real solid places at this time for it to be effective.   So for now I am on tamoxifen and monthly zometa.  I hope that this works and shrinks all the cancer so they shrivel up and go away!  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: My Story - Widespread Bone Mets cheriee Laurie09

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 02:27AM Groovywilma wrote: This month is my one year cancerversary and feel much calmer than that horrible first month of learning I was stage IV right from the start.  I see my oncologist monthly when I get my zometa and also get my blood work done monthly.  I bring an audio recorder to my appointments so I can record all the information we cover and also so my family can hear what the doctor has to say in case I forget to update them.  I get PET scans every three to four months.  Best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 12:57AM Groovywilma wrote: Welcome to all the new people, and a big thanks to all the "not so new" people for the amazing support I've found here.  I was diagnosed stage IV from the get go (lots of mets to bones) January 2011.  I was on Tamoxifen and Zometa since then and just recently switched to Arimidex plus Lupron plus Zometa.  I've been feeling good and recently returned from a trip to Italy!  It was great!  During the trip I was able to take a vacation from cancer, and even today I forgot to update my friend about my health issues because I was so distracted with other things!  Every day life is nice to worry about instead of stage IV cancer.  I'm still working, which has been a good distraction for me also.  Happy Holidays to everyone and lots of positive thoughts going out to you all!
Posts.Title: to all new stage 4 members apple apple

This place is one of the best because the people here are the closest we're going to get to having real understanding of the struggles we go through. The struggle is real! Take care of yourself as much as you can. Wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: How to Keep Going, When All My Go is Gone blainejennifer kachincolor

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2017 07:41AM Groovywilma wrote: Excellent topic! I've been tired, but know that I need to eat to keep up my strength. For me, smoothies in my Vitamix are quick and easy and filling. Just keep frozen fruits in your freezer. You don't have to use milk, you can use almond milk, rice milk, or skip milk and just use water or juice. You can also add yogurt, or anything, really, to help get more nutrients. And it's a quick rinse afterwards! My other secret is my NUWAVE oven. It's great when I haven't planned ahead and want something that's been in the freezer. It takes the cook time down without having to defrost, and you can put all kinds of things in there! Salmon, chicken, frozen pizzas, etc. I'll be following this thread to get more ideas!
Posts.Title: Hungry, but Tired. Meal Ideas? blainejennifer ShetlandPony

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 02:36AM Groovywilma wrote: Hello!  I also have been getting my IV in my arm every month for my zometa for the last 3.5 years.  They usually put it in the inside of my forearm.  My vein is "deep" but if the nurse is good, they can get it.  One of my nurses also likes to use a spot right above my elbow, on the inside.  I'm used to all the pokes and prodding, and I do have "challenging" veins.  What I don't like is the "digging around" after they get in there.  ICK!  Anyhow, I hope your veins are good and plump for your next infusion!

I've done lots of traveling, got a promotion at work, and enjoy lots of time with friends and family doing fun things. Getting information about your treatments and being your own best advocate will help you along the way. Take care!

Posts.Title: my o my apple Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: May 15, 2017 01:20AM Groovywilma wrote: I hope things have improved for you both regarding the constipation. When I was on Gemzar I would notice I couldn't go the same day, and the next day. On the 3rd day when I would go, it would be pebble like. I called it pebble poo. The rest of the week would be back to normal. After a while I started to incorporate Metamucil every day and that helped a lot. the pebble poo became regular poo, but the same day and next day I still usually didn't go. Also later in the game I added prune juice which helped a lot. For sleep, I often had difficulty sleeping the first and second night. I would be able to go to sleep, then I would wake up at 4am and not be able to go back to sleep. It was due to the steroid pre-meds. I started taking sleep aids to help with this, and it did. Wishing you both luck on Gemzar and that you find it manageable and effective for a loooooong time! I was on it for 10 months. I had some fatigue, but it was pretty manageable.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 07:28AM Groovywilma wrote: I am Wilma!  I somehow stumbled onto this site probably around the time I had my breast biopsy in December 2010.  Found out in January 2011 that I have stage IV breast cancer from the get go (boooooo!).  I come and read what's going on pretty regularly but don't post too much.  I try to provide support to new people here as I have received so much support and information here.  I just had my one year cancerversary.  Things are going well (mets to bones) and I am on arimidex plus zometa plus lupron.  I still work full time and I enjoy traveling!  I just came back from a great visit to San Francisco!  Great food, shopping, and fun!  I'm 37 years old.  Best of luck to everyone here!

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2015 11:00AM Groovywilma wrote: Joyfuller and Artistatheart, Very sorry that you have to be here. The information that others have already posted are right on. These anti-hormonal drugs are very powerful. When I was diagnosed stage IV from the start I did not have surgery, chemo, or radiation. I've been on tamoxifen, arimidex, and now faslodex (along with zometa throughout) and it's almost five years later. I'm living my "normal" life, still working, and traveling as much as I can. You will soon find your normal and I hope it is great. Wishing you all the best.
